data.text: Ergon SMC Core Saddle: Is It Worthy?

Hello guys and girls. Really new to cycling any sort of distances. (34 km is my max so far) ‚ò∫Ô∏è but really want to get into touring and keep pushing the distances further. However because I am so new, after riding, my backside feels like I have spent a week in prison. I've read so many reviews and like the sound of the Ergon SMC core saddle. Has anyone had any experience with this saddle or would you recommend a cheaper saddle and better chamois? FYI I only have a hard tail MTB ATM with Ergon GP5 grips and adjusted my sitting position to a slightly straighter one by raising the handlebar. Any advice is greatly received.
Get a bike fit, try chamois cream, buy a multitude of saddles for astronomic prices, then seriously consider getting a recumbet two wheeler üòÇ My story at least..
data.author: Viktor Spett

data.text: What saddle suits me may not suit you. Brooks are popular but do not suit everyone. Your first step should be to a bike shop to get measured for a saddle. It takes 2 minutes and is a good place to start.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: The more you cycle the less problems you'll have. When touring, first days or first 150-200 km can be tough for the backside, but then, it all dissapears...saddles are important, but they don't make miracles...
data.author: Jo Sarmento

data.text: My advice- keep riding and your butt will get tougher! I *think* a less upright position might help. I found that it took a while to get used to riding miles, but one day (without noticing) my butt, wrists, shins etc all stopped hurting! Good luck
data.author: Duncan Brown

data.text: yeah, like, laying down kind of position. with some streamline around you, lets call it a velomobile
data.author: Raymond van Vugt

data.text: If your back hurts, maybe think of strengthening it? Bridges, crunches, stretches, leg lifts while lying should be helpful (and plenty others, but you can Google further if interested)
data.author: Kay Anky JS

data.text: Find some info on - bike fit. - saddle fit. You typically wear padded shorts or use some extra comfy material for the sake. Like leather. An MTB has a higher positioned bottom bracket, to soo you can't follow the bike fit principles fully. Of you do, your feet won't reach the ground. But understanding things helps.
data.author: Mahesh T Pai

data.text: It seems the more upright you are the wider the seat you‚Äôll need. Find a local bike shop and spend some time fitting bike and saddle, should put you in a happier place than that prison feeling.
data.author: Jay Smith

data.text: There is truth to the aspect that the more you ride, you‚Äôll ‚Äúleather up‚Äù your sitting area‚Ä¶. That said‚Ä¶ If you have a bad fit, or the wrong saddle, you will *never* be comfortable, and will always struggle with it. You can research all you want - but on your own, you‚Äôll basically be taking shots in the dark. Take a seat - you can pay $50-$200+ - in a lot of ways, you get what you pay for, but things like titanium rails are less important (to your butt) than the shape/material used. Do you really want to hit and miss buying saddles until you find the right one? That can get expensive, and even if you do find the saddle that‚Äôs a good match, that‚Äôs only *one* element of your fit/comfort. It‚Äôs worth it to stop into a LBS or two‚Ä¶ find one that wants to work with *you* and *your* goals‚Ä¶ spending an hour or so with a fitting will give you instant gratification‚Ä¶ just compare to an hour of your time spent here. ü§™ Everyone here has *their* ideas for what will work for you‚Ä¶ many are actually good, but mostly good for them. Good luck on getting to more comfortable riding!
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: Check out Terry saddles. Most comfortable saddle I‚Äôve used for sitting hours/ riding . Middle cut out for relief in the right places!
data.author: Michael Plowright

data.text: I agree. Love my Terry Fisio saddle!
data.author: Julia Eekels

data.text: .. you live in a beautiful part of the world üåé. One day I hope to ride and experience life there .
data.author: Michael Plowright

data.text: im very lucky indeed! And you should definitely go!
data.author: Julia Eekels

data.text: A good thigh, a good saddle adjustment, patience... sometimes it takes time to get used to it is the case of all beginners but over time you will no longer have pain ;)
data.author: Thierry Le Guellaut

data.text: Or just buy a recumbent
data.author: Raymond van Vugt

data.text: As I build Touring Bikes professionally......always fit a Brooks B17 as all serious tourers swear by them. That said .... a slightly lean forward stance is desirable otherwise a wider saddle needed. Most distance cyclists mould to their bikes....so patience a must for a variety of reasons. Don't measure ability by distance....become at one with the environment, it's a lifestyle game changer . Good luck
data.author: Rod Gates

data.text:
I believe that it is mostly muscle pain so the more you ride the better shape your backside will handle long hours in the saddle. As for saddles... I would go nowhere without my Brooks saddle because the old school leather over time has become part of me. https://www.brooksengland.com/leathersaddles/
Brooks Leather Saddles
brooksengland.com
data.author: Kerry Vanderzalm

data.text: It has never been about km. It‚Äôs our sick society that needs to put a number to happiness. To me it‚Äôs all about how many cm you feel above ground when the joy lifts you above the conventional.
data.author: Giulia Juh√©

data.text:
Most importantly is to setup your bike correctly, what‚Äôs called a bike fit. Check this video, it‚Äôll help you a bit https://youtu.be/clVyZQzTJ0Q A soft saddle never helps. Get a padded shorts, there are MTB specific available too, not the Lycra one, if you not comfortable wearing Lycra. Use a chamois cream/butt butter or simple coconut oil + Vaseline, whatever works. It‚Äôll help avoid the unnecessary soreness because of friction. The more you ride, more you‚Äôll get used to it. Increase your distance by a km or so in your daily ride and about 5 - 10 km on a long ride, once a week. Since you are already doing 34 km, by end of 4-6 weeks, you‚Äôll be able to do a 100 km. However, remember to have a recovery day at least twice a week. Go for a relax short ride, or a walk or just rest at home and stretch. Also, do cool-down stretches after every ride. üçª Happy Pedalling üö¥üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
How To Dial In Your Mountain Bike Fit | MTB Set Up Tips & Tricks
youtube.com
data.author: Junaid Parvez

data.text: Just ride and you'll get used to it
data.author: Craig Brown

data.text: I made 2500km and my butt hurt every day. I also had problems with my knees during the first weeks. Well at home I read on this site, that maybe my saddle isn't adjusted correctly. I asked my bike service for putting it a little longer back and raise the front a little, because I was sliding forward on the saddle. Unfortunately they did raise it way too much. Finally a warmshowers host did adjust it for me. Now it is perfekt and my butt feels fine even without padded trousers.
data.author: Dorothee Hildebrandt

data.text: It's the price of admission into the club
data.author: Lee Davis

data.text: Riding on rocky creeks is what this cane creek seat post was made for. This one is the large model but the smaller is good enough and you save 50 bucks and 50 gramms.
data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text:
For Saddle this one is for big butts: https://www.triathletestore.com/products/selle-smp-martin-touring-gel-saddle
Selle SMP Martin Touring GEL Saddle (Medium)

data.author: Jo En Pausa

data.text: Recumbent
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text:
I like charge spoon saddles, they also seem to fit quite a few people very well, however everyone has different sit bones, they aren't that expensive though so may be worth a try. I ride 100"s of miles a week on the spoon with normal mtb shorts and no liner without any issues. https://www.tredz.co.uk/.Charge-Spoon-Cromo-Saddle_65215.htm Use code XC6M7XBX by adding something to take your order upto ¬£30 for ¬£5 off.
Charge Spoon Cromo Saddle | Tredz Bikes
tredz.co.uk
data.author: Scott Jones

data.text: My personal preference is to sit upright on a hybrid, which I find much more comfortable for my back (I had the same problem when I started). It's not ideal for racing, but I'm more interested in touring.
data.author: Brooke Anderson

data.text: You will need to measure you sit bones, (I'm pretty sure there is a you tube) Sit in piece of cardboard and measure the distance between the indents. edit plus 20-25mm. Then look at saddles in that width. My partner uses a selle smp lite 209. If you go to bike shop, some do loan saddles to try, which can make it easier. I tried a touring saddle and didn't like it. You will get used to it, but first the correct width saddle is the only way to go, along with good chamios bike shorts.
data.author: Michelle Cross

data.text: Find a professional bike fitter that knows his saddles. Mine recommend one that suited me, and I barely get sore and I tour for weeks at a time.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Cofort won't be achieved with a new saddle most likely. It is part of it but only one piece of a larger puzzle. you need a proper bike fit if you want to go long distances. A proper fit will tune saddle height, saddle fore/aft which greatly affect weight on hands, saddle tilt angle, saddle width, handle bar reach (stem length), handle bar height, hoods placement, cleat placement. Then you need to progressively train your body. Your technique also plays a role - poor posture and engaging the wrong muscles will cause discomfort so you need to learn how to pedal correctly and there is more to it than turning the crank. Hybrid bikes are not a solution and will cause more issues. A road/touring/gravel bike is better suited for long distances. Invest in a professional bike fit. Don t be overwhelmed but like any sport you need to invest yourself in leaning proper technique and tuning your equipment to be able to raise your level and increase your endurance.
data.author: Martin Chalifoux

data.text: Recumbents will fix all types of soreness usually caused by the bad ergonomics of uprights. But a nice upright position and a few different hand positions should be enough. Butt gets used to it, but if you have the cash then a leather saddle is a good investment.
data.author: Pedro Claro

data.text:
First off all, for every new activity your body needs a time to adopt. So don't give up, for me personally it's normally around three weeks. Find some more useful info here: https://weonbikes.com/en/blog/how-to-choose-your-saddle/
How to choose the right bike saddle in 7 steps
weonbikes.com
data.author: Menno van Balen

data.text: Go to a bikefitter who will check out your position but also let you try out different seats to check the pressure on your bum!
data.author: Emily Scherer
